class_notes: Microhistory is a historical method that focuses on a single event, person, object, or place as a means of understanding broader historical questions. Students in this course will explore how historians have written these fascinating historical narratives as well as practice examining primary sources and conducting archival research as we work toward our shared goal of writing microhistory ourselves. We will pay particular attention to the lives of ordinary people in different parts of the world between the sixteenth and nineteenth centuries.
course_description: All history majors except those who complete the Honors Program must take two colloquia (HIST 487, 488 or 489). Each colloquium treats a special theme by reading, discussion, and writing of papers. Enrollment in each is limited to twelve; non-majors are welcome within space limitations.
